label.text: Offshore Wind Turbine Farm
A coastal town is considering constructing an offshore wind turbine farm to generate electricty.
Wind causes the blades on a wind turbine to turn, which generates electricity. The electricity is added to the electricity network onshore.
Some people in the town are in favour of the project. Other people are concerned that the project will have a negative impact on the local environment.
An offshore wind turbine farm
turbine
blade
Explain one way in which the environment benefits when electricity is generated using wind instead of fossil fuels.
Describe one negative impact that the wind farm could have on the local environment.
Up to 90% of the components of a wind turbine can be recycled, but not the blades. The blades contain a resin that is difficult to separate from the other materials.
What action should be taken to reduce waste from the stockpile of old blades?
No action should be taken because the non-recyclable waste is only 10%.
Techniques should be developed for recycling old blades.
New blades should be developed, made of components that are easy to recycle.
New wind turbines should be designed that work without blades.
The town decides to go ahead with constructing the offshore wind turbine farm.
Wind turbines have to be anchored to the seabed. The deeper the seabed the more expensive it is to install the turbines.

Consider this information about the zones:
Zone A is visited by large numbers of seabirds every day.
Zone B supports green algae, a critical source of food for many marine organisms.
Zones B and C support shoals of common fish species.
Zone D is deep enough to allow large marine animals to swim through it.
In which zone should the wind turbines be installed as the best compromise between cost and environmental impact?
Explain your choice.
